"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...> writes:

> From: "Nic Ferrier" <nferrier@...>
> >
> > It's my belief that basic authentication could be fixed as a device
> > for doing web authentication if the user agents always displayed the
> > entity from the server.
> 
> Except that entity already has a use:  to be displayed if the user hits the
> cancel button.  An alternative might be to provide a new response header
> during challenges that points a browser to a server-defined skin (possibly
> using the technique S. Mike found in the W3C Note).  Newer browsers that
> recognized the header would  be able to give a more "polished" look, while
> older browsers would continue working without problem.

You misunderstand me.

When a user requests a protected resource the server can send back an
entity body with the initial 401. The rfc says that the entity is for
when the response fails - but that should only happen after a
challenge has been sent. 

Therefore, if browsers displayed any entity body sent by the server
when no challenge has been sent the entity body could be used to
provide a "normal" authentication FORM (ie: a username and password
POSTing to some place).

In other words the entity body from the server replaces the login
dialog box for the user.

This would fit in with the way most web applications want to do
authentication and it's REST compliant (as far as I can see).


Nic
